action.content:
Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: tin, psychology, poland, brass, volleyball, germany, golf, physics, medicine.
Your opponent's team words are: sunflower, jeep, mum, tractor, pansy, airplane, truck, petunia.
Distractor words are: tomato, celery, cucumber, island, electrician, dentist, plain.
The kill words are: whiskey.
action.label: context

action.content:
<think>
Okay, let's see. I need to come up with a single-word clue that relates to some of my team's words. The team words are tin, psychology, poland, brass, volleyball, germany, golf, physics, medicine. The opponent's words are sunflower, jeep, mum, tractor, pansy, airplane, truck, petunia. Distractors are tomato, celery, cucumber, island, electrician, dentist, plain. Kill word is whiskey.

First, I should look for connections among the team's words. Let's list them again: tin, psychology, poland, brass, volleyball, germany, golf, physics, medicine. Hmm. Tin and brass are both metals. Psychology and physics are both "ologies" or scientific fields. Germany and Poland are countries. Volleyball and golf are sports. Medicine is a field related to health. Maybe there's a way to group some of these.

If I think about metals, tin and brass are both metals. But maybe that's too narrow. Psychology and physics are both "ology" words. But maybe "science" could be a clue? Psychology, physics, medicine are all sciences. But then what about the others? Germany and Poland are countries, but maybe not directly related to science. Volleyball and golf are sports. Hmm.

Alternatively, maybe "instruments"? Brass is a type of instrument (like brass instruments in music), but volleyball and golf aren't instruments. Wait,
action.label: response

content.message: Your answer contained more than two lines, please only give one clue and your targets on two separate lines.
